conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light from a source, casting a silhouette on a surface.
The size and position of the shadow depend on the relative positions of the light source, the object, and the surface.
There are four objects casting shadows labeled A, B, C, and D.
The light source is currently positioned such that these shadows are visible on the ground.
As the light source moves backwards, the angle at which light hits the objects changes, causing shadows to elongate and move further away from the objects.
The further the light source is from the objects, the larger the shadows become because the light rays are more parallel, causing the shadow to stretch.
Shadow A will elongate and move further away from the object casting it, and its size will increase as the light source moves backwards.
Shadow B will elongate and increase in size, moving further from the object.
Shadow C will experience elongation and size increase, moving further from the object casting it.
Shadow D will elongate and increase in size, moving further from the object.
As the light source moves backwards, all shadows (A, B, C, and D) will elongate, increase in size, and move further away from their respective objects.
